SHERIFF'S SALES.
Br PETER b. DEL.A.NY. ,SHEBrFl

Our readers will perceive that the subject Of the British
Colonial Trade is before branch as in few days l.
must be considered by the other branch Of Congress hev
will also remark that there great diversity of opinion
regard it. This to have been expected from the
extraordinary pursued by the British Government
and from the compexy Of the British legislation in regard
their colonies In very able speech delivered few
days ago by Mr. Johnston of Louisiana, in the Senate, dis
playing great diligence ard thorough knowledge Of the


subject the part Of that Senator he stated that the con-


fusion and uncertainty of the British statutes such, that
learned Judge, (no other than Sir William Scott had re-
Gently decided, in the OF the Jubilee question OF
salvage without being that the statute which he
placed his opinion repealed by the Act Of Parliament
Of 1926 And yet it required by Great Britain that.
without any official communication of that act any Off
cial explanation Of lis provisions the American Govern
ment should comprehend the import of a British law.
which the first judge in England did not understand In
dependent of all other considerations this state Of uncer
tainy of the British laws demonstrates the propriey OF the
opinion Of the Executive, that better that the Colo
NAL Intercourse should be regulated by treaty than egisa
ton. indeed, we understand MIR. 1arerci who was
of the most urgent members for the passage OF act
of Congress the last session, admitting that any
act which may be passed will only be the basis of negoaH
nan Such is undoub edly the case. Now il We are !"
end it have begun. with negeation Pre-
yous legislation is attended with the disadvantage Of expo
sing the other parry the first instance the uiinatn,
and thus bring the chance of obtaining better terms

Post Road from baltimore to Phiiadeiplaia.-~
The report Of the Engineers on this subject, laid
before Congress on Monday last, by the Postmaster
General comprises the examination Of eight differ
en' routes, which are all denes'ed on map, ac-
companying the report, and passing respectively, BY
the following places


| First Route-Baltimore, Abingdon, Bush, Hall Cross
Road Havre de ferry, North East Elkon Newark
Stanton Newport. Wilmington, Practical Farmer Marcus
Hook, Chester. Darby, Hamionville, Philadelphia.
Second Observation-Disclosures, Abingdon, Bush, Rock Ran,
Port Deposite Bridge Northeast. Elkon Newark, San


ton Newpor Wilmingon Practical Farmer. Marcus Hook,
Chester, Darby, Hamilonville, Phisdslphia.
! Third Route.--Ba,more, Great Gunpowder lower
Bridge, Port Depose Bridge, Newark, Stanton, Newport
wmngton pseea fsms, Marcus Hook Chester
| Fourth Route.-Batimore, Great Genpowder upper
Bridge, Copper Factory, Belle Air. Ch'irchve Port De-
posite Bridge, Newark, Stanton, Newport Wilmington
Practical Farmer Marcus Hook, Chester, Darby, lan-
tohvile, Philadelphia.


Fifth Rome.-Bamore. Great Gnpowder lower Bridge
Port Deposte Bridge Brick Westinghouse New London
Cross Roads, Kennet's Square, Chad's Ford, Concord,
wrangetown, Darby. IIamiltonville, Philadelpha.
SirM Rous-Baltimore, Great Gunpowder upper
bridge. Copper Factory Belle AR Churchye, Port De-
Roads. Kenncts Square, Chads Ford, Concord, Wrange
town. Darby, Hauillonville, Philadelphia.


Stventh Route Baltimore. Great Gunpowder upper
bridge, Copper Factory, Belle Air Dublin, Conewingo
Bridge, New London Cross Road Kennels Square, Chad's
Ford Concord Wrangletown Darby, Hsmltonvile, Phil
Eighth Route-Baltimore. Great Gunpowder upper
bridge, Copper Factory. Belle Air, Dublin, Conewingo


Bridge, New London Cross Roads, Chad's Ford Hamilton
vile. Philadelphia.


From comparison OF the several routes, il has
been determined that the first would be the short.
est and would admit OF the easiest graduation; but
that the second, TO expense, has the advantage
and that in combining together distances graduation
and expense, the second route has claims to prefer
ence. In this opinion OF the Engineers the Post-
master General has expressed his concurrence.--
The length Of the second route is found TO be nine
iyseven miles and sixty six yards; and the expense
Of constructing il is estimated at one hundred and
twenty six thousand eight hundred and thirty nine
dollars.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.

Physicians. There is no class or profession Of
men who appear 10 the world to have so little res
pee, or courtesy towards each other as physicians.
They seem often to regard each other as rivals to
be vanqushed, rather than associates in high and
liberal art. We think it therefore to the credit of
the physicians of Boston, that they have agreed to
have "medicai conversazione," regularly once a
month, the object of which is to cultivate feelings Of
friendship among the profession, TO communicate q.
ny important facts which may have come to the
knowledge OF any one Of them, and generally to pro-
mote the extension of medical knowledge.

Time.-An Italian philosopher expresses in his
motto, thst time was his estate-an estate indeed
which will produce nothing without cultivation, but
will always abundsniy repsy the labors OF industry
and generally satisfy the most extensive Desires if
no part Of ii be suffered to waste BY negligence, 70
be overrun with noxious plants, or laid out for show
r,,h.r than for use. Ram bier.


We may learn to brook any disappointment ex-
cent that which affects our character. One OF that
kind stinr, " too acutely TO be soon forgotten.

From the London Literary Souvenr.


By NH. t. HOOD.
Oh when was a tiny boy
My days and nights were full of JOY,
My mates we're blthe and kind -
No wonder that sometimes sigh,
And dash the tear drop from my eye,
To cast look behind!
A hoop was an eternal round
OF pleasure. In those days found
A top joyous thing;- -
But now those past delights drop.
My head, alas is all my top,
And careful thoughts the string.
My marbles--once my bag was stored,-
Now must play with Elgin's lord,
With Theseus for a saw
My playful horse has slipt his string,
Forgotten all his capering,


And harness'd to the law
NV kite-how fast and far il few.
Whilst !, sort of Franklin, drew
My pleasure from the sky!
Twas paper'd o'e- with studious themes,
The tasks wrote-my present dreams
Will never soar SO high!
My Joys are wingless all and dead.
My dumps are made of more than lead,
My flights soon find fall;
My fears prevail, my fances droop,
Joy never cometh with hoop.
And seldom with call
My footballs laid upon the shelf
l Am shuttecock myself


The world knocks TO and fro;-
My archery is all unlearn'd,
And grief against myself has turn'd
My arrows and my bow!
No more in noon,ide sun bask;
Ny authorships All endless task,
Nv head's ne 'cr out of school
My heart is pain'd with scorn and slight,
have too many foes to fight,
And friends grown strangely cool!
The very chum that shared my cake
Holds out SO cold hand to shake,
L. makes me shrink and sigh
On this will not dwell and hang,
The changeling would not feel pang
Though these should never meet his eye!
No skies SO blue, or so serene
As then mo leaves look half SO green
As clothed the playground tree
All thingsI loved are alterd 50.
Nor does it ease my heart 70 know
That change resides in me!
Oh, for the garb that mark d the boy.
The trowsers made of corduroy,


Well mixed with black and red:
The crowness hat, ne'er deem'd an ILL
II only let the sunshine still


Repose upon my head!
Oh. for the riband round the neck:
The careless dogs cars apt TO deck


My book and collar both
How can this formal man be styled
Merely all Alexantrine child,


boy of larger growth
oh, for that small, small beer anew
And (heaven's own type) that milk, sky-blue,
That washed my sweet meals down;
The master even land that small Turk
That fagg'd me worse is now my work
A fag for all the town!
oh, for the lesson learn'd by heart
Ay, though the very blrchs smart


Should mark those hours again;
I'D kiss the rod, and be resign'd
Beneath the stroke, and even find


Some sugar in the cane
The Arabian Nights rehearsed in bed,
The Fairy Tales in school time read,


BY stealth, twixt verb and noun
The angel form that always walk'd
III all my dreams, and look'd and talk'd


Exactly like Miss Brown!
The on,ne bene-- Christmas come
The prize of merit, won for home


Merit had prizes then!
Hut now write for days and days.
For fame-a deal of empty praise


Without the silver pen!
Then home, sweet home the crowded COACH
The JOYOUS shout--the loud approach


The winding horns like rams!
The meeting sweet that made me thrill,
The sweetmeats almost sweeter still,


No salts to the 'jamsn--
When that was tiny boy
My days and nights were full of joy


NV mates were blithe and kind!
No wonder that sometimes sigh,
And dash the teardrcp from my eye.


To cast look behind!



There is no class or professio
n who appear 10 the world to have so little

full articles.headline: THE COLONIAL TRADE.
full articles.article:
Our readers will perceive that the subject Of the British
Colonial Trade is before branch as in few days l.
must be considered by the other branch Of Congress hev
will also remark that there great diversity of opinion
regard it. This to have been expected from the
extraordinary pursued by the British Government
and from the compexy Of the British legislation in regard
their colonies In very able speech delivered few
days ago by Mr. Johnston of Louisiana, in the Senate, dis
playing great diligence ard thorough knowledge Of the


subject the part Of that Senator he stated that the con-


fusion and uncertainty of the British statutes such, that
learned Judge, (no other than Sir William Scott had re-
Gently decided, in the OF the Jubilee question OF
salvage without being that the statute which he
placed his opinion repealed by the Act Of Parliament
Of 1926 And yet it required by Great Britain that.
without any official communication of that act any Off
cial explanation Of lis provisions the American Govern
ment should comprehend the import of a British law.
which the first judge in England did not understand In
dependent of all other considerations this state Of uncer
tainy of the British laws demonstrates the propriey OF the
opinion Of the Executive, that better that the Colo
NAL Intercourse should be regulated by treaty than egisa
ton. indeed, we understand MIR. 1arerci who was
of the most urgent members for the passage OF act
of Congress the last session, admitting that any
act which may be passed will only be the basis of negoaH
nan Such is undoub edly the case. Now il We are !"
end it have begun. with negeation Pre-
yous legislation is attended with the disadvantage Of expo
sing the other parry the first instance the uiinatn,
and thus bring the chance of obtaining better terms


Nat Journal.

full articles.article:
Post Road from baltimore to Phiiadeiplaia.-~
The report Of the Engineers on this subject, laid
before Congress on Monday last, by the Postmaster
General comprises the examination Of eight differ
en' routes, which are all denes'ed on map, ac-
companying the report, and passing respectively, BY
the following places


| First Route-Baltimore, Abingdon, Bush, Hall Cross
Road Havre de ferry, North East Elkon Newark
Stanton Newport. Wilmington, Practical Farmer Marcus
Hook, Chester. Darby, Hamionville, Philadelphia.
Second Observation-Disclosures, Abingdon, Bush, Rock Ran,
Port Deposite Bridge Northeast. Elkon Newark, San


ton Newpor Wilmingon Practical Farmer. Marcus Hook,
Chester, Darby, Hamilonville, Phisdslphia.
! Third Route.--Ba,more, Great Gunpowder lower
Bridge, Port Depose Bridge, Newark, Stanton, Newport
wmngton pseea fsms, Marcus Hook Chester
| Fourth Route.-Batimore, Great Genpowder upper
Bridge, Copper Factory, Belle Air. Ch'irchve Port De-
posite Bridge, Newark, Stanton, Newport Wilmington
Practical Farmer Marcus Hook, Chester, Darby, lan-
tohvile, Philadelphia.


Fifth Rome.-Bamore. Great Gnpowder lower Bridge
Port Deposte Bridge Brick Westinghouse New London
Cross Roads, Kennet's Square, Chad's Ford, Concord,
wrangetown, Darby. IIamiltonville, Philadelpha.
SirM Rous-Baltimore, Great Gunpowder upper
bridge. Copper Factory Belle AR Churchye, Port De-
Roads. Kenncts Square, Chads Ford, Concord, Wrange
town. Darby, Hauillonville, Philadelphia.


Stventh Route Baltimore. Great Gunpowder upper
bridge, Copper Factory, Belle Air Dublin, Conewingo
Bridge, New London Cross Road Kennels Square, Chad's
Ford Concord Wrangletown Darby, Hsmltonvile, Phil
Eighth Route-Baltimore. Great Gunpowder upper
bridge, Copper Factory. Belle Air, Dublin, Conewingo


Bridge, New London Cross Roads, Chad's Ford Hamilton
vile. Philadelphia.


From comparison OF the several routes, il has
been determined that the first would be the short.
est and would admit OF the easiest graduation; but
that the second, TO expense, has the advantage
and that in combining together distances graduation
and expense, the second route has claims to prefer
ence. In this opinion OF the Engineers the Post-
master General has expressed his concurrence.--
The length Of the second route is found TO be nine
iyseven miles and sixty six yards; and the expense
Of constructing il is estimated at one hundred and
twenty six thousand eight hundred and thirty nine
dollars.


1t i, not expected, we believe, that the subject
will be acted upon by the present Congress- Intel.
Washington, February Is The SENATE yesterday pas
sed the bills granting to the States OF Illinois and ln


ana donations Of land Give sections deep on each slde
every alternate section, through the whole q
each cana to aid those States in the construction Of

Physicians. There is no class or profession Of
men who appear 10 the world to have so little res
pee, or courtesy towards each other as physicians.
They seem often to regard each other as rivals to
be vanqushed, rather than associates in high and
liberal art. We think it therefore to the credit of
the physicians of Boston, that they have agreed to
have "medicai conversazione," regularly once a
month, the object of which is to cultivate feelings Of
friendship among the profession, TO communicate q.
ny important facts which may have come to the
knowledge OF any one Of them, and generally to pro-
mote the extension of medical knowledge.

Time.-An Italian philosopher expresses in his
motto, thst time was his estate-an estate indeed
which will produce nothing without cultivation, but
will always abundsniy repsy the labors OF industry
and generally satisfy the most extensive Desires if
no part Of ii be suffered to waste BY negligence, 70
be overrun with noxious plants, or laid out for show
r,,h.r than for use. Ram bier.


We may learn to brook any disappointment ex-
cent that which affects our character. One OF that
kind stinr, " too acutely TO be soon forgotten.

full articles.headline: From the London Literary Souuenir.
full articles.article:
From the London Literary Souvenr.


By NH. t. HOOD.
Oh when was a tiny boy
My days and nights were full of JOY,
My mates we're blthe and kind -
No wonder that sometimes sigh,
And dash the tear drop from my eye,
To cast look behind!
A hoop was an eternal round
OF pleasure. In those days found
A top joyous thing;- -
But now those past delights drop.
My head, alas is all my top,
And careful thoughts the string.
My marbles--once my bag was stored,-
Now must play with Elgin's lord,
With Theseus for a saw
My playful horse has slipt his string,
Forgotten all his capering,


And harness'd to the law
NV kite-how fast and far il few.
Whilst !, sort of Franklin, drew
My pleasure from the sky!
Twas paper'd o'e- with studious themes,
The tasks wrote-my present dreams
Will never soar SO high!
My Joys are wingless all and dead.
My dumps are made of more than lead,
My flights soon find fall;
My fears prevail, my fances droop,
Joy never cometh with hoop.
And seldom with call
My footballs laid upon the shelf
l Am shuttecock myself


The world knocks TO and fro;-
My archery is all unlearn'd,
And grief against myself has turn'd
My arrows and my bow!
No more in noon,ide sun bask;
Ny authorships All endless task,
Nv head's ne 'cr out of school
My heart is pain'd with scorn and slight,
have too many foes to fight,
And friends grown strangely cool!
The very chum that shared my cake
Holds out SO cold hand to shake,
L. makes me shrink and sigh
On this will not dwell and hang,
The changeling would not feel pang
Though these should never meet his eye!
No skies SO blue, or so serene
As then mo leaves look half SO green
As clothed the playground tree
All thingsI loved are alterd 50.
Nor does it ease my heart 70 know
That change resides in me!
Oh, for the garb that mark d the boy.
The trowsers made of corduroy,


Well mixed with black and red:
The crowness hat, ne'er deem'd an ILL
II only let the sunshine still


Repose upon my head!
Oh. for the riband round the neck:
The careless dogs cars apt TO deck


My book and collar both
How can this formal man be styled
Merely all Alexantrine child,


boy of larger growth
oh, for that small, small beer anew
And (heaven's own type) that milk, sky-blue,
That washed my sweet meals down;
The master even land that small Turk
That fagg'd me worse is now my work
A fag for all the town!
oh, for the lesson learn'd by heart
Ay, though the very blrchs smart


Should mark those hours again;
I'D kiss the rod, and be resign'd
Beneath the stroke, and even find


Some sugar in the cane
The Arabian Nights rehearsed in bed,
The Fairy Tales in school time read,


BY stealth, twixt verb and noun
The angel form that always walk'd
III all my dreams, and look'd and talk'd


Exactly like Miss Brown!
The on,ne bene-- Christmas come
The prize of merit, won for home


Merit had prizes then!
Hut now write for days and days.
For fame-a deal of empty praise


Without the silver pen!
Then home, sweet home the crowded COACH
The JOYOUS shout--the loud approach


The winding horns like rams!
The meeting sweet that made me thrill,
The sweetmeats almost sweeter still,


No salts to the 'jamsn--
When that was tiny boy
My days and nights were full of joy


NV mates were blithe and kind!
No wonder that sometimes sigh,
And dash the teardrcp from my eye.


To cast look behind!



There is no class or professio
n who appear 10 the world to have so little

for the plaintiff, one hundred dollars damages
